title: SQLRIGHT JOIN Keyword

metadata.description: Learn about SQLRIGHT JOIN Keyword with clear explanations and practical examples.

content_sections.title: Details
content_sections.content:
Reference

❯
RIGHT JOIN
The
RIGHT JOIN
command returns all rows from 
the right table, and the matching records from the left table. The result is 
NULL from the left side, when there is no match.
The following SQL will return all employees, and any orders they 
might have placed:
Example
SELECT Orders.OrderID, Employees.LastName, Employees.FirstName
FROM Orders
RIGHT JOIN Employees ON Orders.EmployeeID = Employees.EmployeeID
ORDER BY Orders.OrderID;

Note:
The
RIGHT JOIN
keyword returns all records from the 
right table (Employees), even if there are no matches in the left table 
(Orders).

Reference

❯
★
+1

content_sections.title: Example
content_sections.code:
SELECT Orders.OrderID, Employees.LastName, Employees.FirstName
FROM Orders
RIGHT JOIN Employees ON Orders.EmployeeID = Employees.EmployeeID
ORDER BY Orders.OrderID;

practice_exercises.solution:
SELECT Orders.OrderID, Employees.LastName, Employees.FirstName
FROM Orders
RIGHT JOIN Employees ON Orders.EmployeeID = Employees.EmployeeID
ORDER BY Orders.OrderID;

summary: This tutorial covers SQLRIGHT JOIN Keyword concepts and techniques. You'll learn how to use SQLRIGHT JOIN Keyword effectively, including key principles, common patterns, and practical examples. By the end of this tutorial, you'll have a solid understanding of SQLRIGHT JOIN Keyword and how to apply it in your projects.
